result.markdown:
--- title: "Tables for Word in `flextable`" date: "2024-05-17" categories: - tables --- ::: {.cell hash='index_cache/html/setup_2ba6a52b786234c62804130cb975095e'} ```{.r .cell-code code-fold="true" code-summary="Setup"} library(tidyverse) library(gt) library(flextable) ``` ::: On those occasions where I have a coauthor working in Word rather than LaTeX, it's sometimes useful to be able to output nicely formatted, editable tables directly from R. I like the tables from `gt`, but they don't render certain style and formatting options correctly in Word or RTF output (see [this issue](https://github.com/rstudio/gt/issues/1098)).[^1] [^1]: If you're reading this some time in the future, it might be worth checking that issue to see if it's been resolved. So, in this post I'll show some tables made with `flextable`, which has better Word support. ::: {.callout-tip collapse="true"} ## If you don't need editability or formatting... There are a few options if you don't need editable output, or output with fancy formatting. ### Editable but not pretty The option I use the most, for sending tables to Word or Excel is `clipr::write_clip(df)`, which writes `df` to the clipboard for easy pasting. There's also `clipr::write_last_clip()` which can be called right after you create a dataframe and copies it to the clipboard. ### Pretty but not editable Another option is to save a `gt` as an image or a pdf: ::: {.cell hash='index_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-2_616f4fdad053735409b90803b1568825'} ```{.r .cell-code} head(mtcars, 3) |> gt() |> gtsave("table.png") # or table.pdf, or whatever ``` ::: (Saving as an image requires that `webshot2` be installed.) ::: ## `flextable` Piping a dataframe to `flextable()` produces a pretty decent initial result: ::: {.cell hash='index_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-3_415929d359642b80ec85801c96ca9084'} ```{.r .cell-code} palmerpenguins::penguins |> select(species, island, bill_length_mm, sex, year) |> slice_sample(n = 5) |> # select 5 random rows flextable() ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ```{=html}

species

island

bill_length_mm

sex

year

Gentoo

Biscoe

49.1

male

2,009

Adelie

Dream

39.5

female

2,007

Chinstrap

Dream

46.8

female

2,009

Gentoo

Biscoe

46.8

female

2,009

Adelie

Biscoe

40.6

male

2,008

``` ::: ::: While we're at it, let's change the formatting of that `year` column. `colformat_num` targets numeric columns; the `j` argument narrows it down to specific columns if needed. `colformat_num` passes `...` to `format()`, so you can use most `format()` arguments---here I've just used `big.mark`. ::: {.cell hash='index_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-4_2c7dcb743a24581be07e10080f838c30'} ```{.r .cell-code} penguin_flextable_1 <- palmerpenguins::penguins |> select(species, island, bill_length_mm, sex, year) |> slice_sample(n = 5) |> flextable() |> colformat_num(j = "year", big.mark = "") penguin_flextable_1 ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ```{=html}

species

island

bill_length_mm

sex

year

Chinstrap

Dream

49.0

male

2008

Gentoo

Biscoe

52.2

male

2009

Adelie

Dream

42.2

female

2007

Gentoo

Biscoe

50.8

male

2009

Adelie

Dream

42.3

male

2007

``` ::: ::: You can also format columns with a function using `set_formatter()`. We could, for example, make the `species` column lowercase and the `island` column uppercase: ::: {.cell hash='index_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-5_f6d0c791c17d91afb9c6c777ea523d28'} ```{.r .cell-code} penguin_flextable_1 |> set_formatter(species = tolower, island = toupper) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ```{=html}

species

island

bill_length_mm

sex

year

chinstrap

DREAM

49.0

male

2008

gentoo

BISCOE

52.2

male

2009

adelie

DREAM

42.2

female

2007

gentoo

BISCOE

50.8

male

2009

adelie

DREAM

42.3

male

2007

``` ::: ::: You can also pass a anonymous function if you need to specify arguments: ::: {.cell hash='index_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-6_f434c4241fec5a5c1db51d9cdd449f03'} ```{.r .cell-code} penguin_flextable_1 |> set_formatter(sex = \(x) ifelse(x == "male", "m", "f")) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ```{=html}

species

island

bill_length_mm

sex

year

Chinstrap

Dream

49.0

m

2008

Gentoo

Biscoe

52.2

m

2009

Adelie

Dream

42.2

f

2007

Gentoo

Biscoe

50.8

m

2009

Adelie

Dream

42.3

m

2007

``` ::: ::: A particularly good use of this is using one of the labeller functions from `scales`, e.g. if you want to format currency: ::: {.cell hash='index_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-7_74bd0fd1f5da3828583d640040e89b38'} ```{.r .cell-code} data.frame(A = c(12.1, 21.56, 3.64), B = c(44.0, 54.44, 6)) |> flextable() |> set_formatter(A = scales::label_dollar()) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ```{=html}

A

B

$12.10

44.00

$21.56

54.44

$3.64

6.00

``` ::: ::: ### Multiple heading levels/grouping You can also make fairly nice tables with a grouping structure in the header using `separate_header()`. This function will interpret column names with a separator (e.g. "\_" as groups and sub-groups. Consider the following (unremarkable) dataframe which summarizes penguin bill length by `species` and `sex`: ::: {.cell hash='index_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-8_35ce7332206388a0c0f180a290487905'} ```{.r .cell-code} penguin_data <- palmerpenguins::penguins |> select(species, sex, bill_length_mm, year) |> drop_na(sex) |> group_by(species, sex, year) |> summarize(bill.length = mean(bill_length_mm), .groups = "drop") penguin_data |> slice_sample(n = 5) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display}
|species |sex | year| bill.length| |:---------|:------|----:|-----------:| |Adelie |female | 2008| 36.51600| |Gentoo |female | 2009| 46.26000| |Chinstrap |female | 2008| 46.00000| |Gentoo |male | 2008| 48.53913| |Chinstrap |male | 2009| 51.10000|
::: ::: Let's pipe that into `flextable`, repeat the `year` column formatting from before, and also round the `bill.length` column to 2 digits. ::: {.cell hash='index_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-9_a2ab1e8f468e72b4e2cd1eba640e0ce1'} ```{.r .cell-code} penguin_flextable_2 <- penguin_data |> slice_sample(n = 5) |> flextable() |> colformat_num(j = "year", big.mark = "") |> colformat_double(digits = 2) penguin_flextable_2 ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ```{=html}

species

sex

year

bill.length

Chinstrap

male

2008

51.40

Gentoo

female

2009

46.26

Chinstrap

female

2009

47.01

Gentoo

male

2007

49.00

Chinstrap

female

2008

46.00

``` ::: ::: We can make this a lot easier to read if we have species and island as header rows. We'll start by `pivot_wider`-ing these two columns. Note that `pivot_wider` defaults to combining `species` and `island` with an underscore (this becomes important momentarily): ::: {.cell hash='index_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-10_26d88fe3d4a991c9d8ee46d3416739bf'} ```{.r .cell-code} penguin_flextable_3 <- penguin_data |> pivot_wider(names_from = c("species", "sex"), values_from = "bill.length") |> flextable() |> colformat_num(j = "year", big.mark = "") |> # reapply our formatting from before colformat_double(digits = 2) penguin_flextable_3 ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ```{=html}

year

Adelie_female

Adelie_male

Chinstrap_female

Chinstrap_male

Gentoo_female

Gentoo_male

2007

37.92

39.95

46.57

50.88

45.06

49.00

2008

36.52

40.60

46.00

51.40

45.30

48.54

2009

37.41

40.56

47.01

51.10

46.26

50.88

``` ::: ::: `separate_header()` parses the column names using the underscore, and makes two header levels: ::: {.cell hash='index_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-11_18a495bb65bda38be594534b856a24c5'} ```{.r .cell-code} penguin_flextable_4 <- penguin_flextable_3 |> separate_header() penguin_flextable_4 ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ```{=html}

year

Adelie

Chinstrap

Gentoo

female

male

female

male

female

male

2007

37.92

39.95

46.57

50.88

45.06

49.00

2008

36.52

40.60

46.00

51.40

45.30

48.54

2009

37.41

40.56

47.01

51.10

46.26

50.88

``` ::: ::: You can change separator with \`separate_header(..., split = "...regex..."). This is useful if your variable names already use underscore as a separator. Note that since in the combined column names, `species` comes before `sex` (e.g. `Adelie_male`), it's been used as the top header row. If you switch the order of the `names_from` argument in `pivot_wider`, you get `sex` as the top row. This gives a slightly unexpected result: why are female/male repeated across each category? ::: {.cell hash='index_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-12_b222db54dbc72aec5b566121329a5c46'} ```{.r .cell-code} penguin_data |> pivot_wider(names_from = c("sex", "species"), values_from = "bill.length") |> flextable() |> separate_header() |> colformat_num(j = "year", big.mark = "") |> # reapply our formatting from before colformat_double(digits = 2) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ```{=html}

year

female

male

female

male

female

male

Adelie

Adelie

Chinstrap

Chinstrap

Gentoo

Gentoo

2007

37.92

39.95

46.57

50.88

45.06

49.00

2008

36.52

40.60

46.00

51.40

45.30

48.54

2009

37.41

40.56

47.01

51.10

46.26

50.88

``` ::: ::: `separate_header()` doesn't rearrange columns to put relevant groups next to each other. If you want a spanning column, you'll need to reorder the columns manually with `relocate()`: ::: {.cell hash='index_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-13_037a7e5490e1d3bf6c2fcaa57fad599e'} ```{.r .cell-code} penguin_data |> pivot_wider(names_from = c("sex", "species"), values_from = "bill.length") |> relocate(starts_with("female")) |> flextable() |> separate_header() |> colformat_num(j = "year", big.mark = "") |> # reapply our formatting from before colformat_double(digits = 2) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ```{=html}

female

year

male

Adelie

Chinstrap

Gentoo

Adelie

Chinstrap

Gentoo

37.92

46.57

45.06

2007

39.95

50.88

49.00

36.52

46.00

45.30

2008

40.60

51.40

48.54

37.41

47.01

46.26

2009

40.56

51.10

50.88

``` ::: ::: With savvy use of `pivot_wider(names_from = ...)` combined with `relocate`, you can the ordering of header rows and spanning columns you're after. ### Change labels We can edit text/values with `labelizor()`. The example below changes all instances of female/male to f/m: ::: {.cell hash='index_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-14_770566dd03fd8e036a45814405e227eb'} ```{.r .cell-code} penguin_flextable_4 |> labelizor(labels = c("female" = "f", "male" = "m")) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ```{=html}

year

Adelie

Chinstrap

Gentoo

f

m

f

m

f

m

2007

37.92

39.95

46.57

50.88

45.06

49.00

2008

36.52

40.60

46.00

51.40

45.30

48.54

2009

37.41

40.56

47.01

51.10

46.26

50.88

``` ::: ::: Adding the `j` argument selects columns to restrict the changes to: ::: {.cell hash='index_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-15_a34603f605eeda6dbd05823efea9532a'} ```{.r .cell-code} penguin_flextable_4 |> labelizor(j = c("Adelie_female", "Chinstrap_female"), labels = c("female" = "f", "male" = "m")) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ```{=html}

year

Adelie

Chinstrap

Gentoo

f

male

f

male

female

male

2007

37.92

39.95

46.57

50.88

45.06

49.00

2008

36.52

40.60

46.00

51.40

45.30

48.54

2009

37.41

40.56

47.01

51.10

46.26

50.88

``` ::: ::: Note that for the `j` argument, the rownames are based on the underlying `df`, not what you seen in the flextable. That's why I have to refer to `Adelie_female`, which was one of the columns that resulted from out `pivot_wider()`ing. You can do a lot with `j` (and in other functions that support it, `i` for rows), including using logical expressions to filter columns. [See here](https://ardata-fr.github.io/flextable-book/table-design.html#usage) for more details. The `labels` argument takes name-value pairs where the name is the value to replace and the value is the replacement value. ### Conditional formatting You can target cells with specific values for various kinds of formatting. For example, `color()` sets the text color. The `color` argument takes either a vector of colors or a function which returns a vector of colors---here I've just used an anonymous function to color code based on whether a value is below or above 40: ::: {.cell hash='index_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-16_e29c45194f0902a1a0f53b6fd1aa10ea'} ```{.r .cell-code} penguin_flextable_4 |> color(color = \(x) ifelse(x < 40, "red", "black")) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ```{=html}

year

Adelie

Chinstrap

Gentoo

female

male

female

male

female

male

2007

37.92

39.95

46.57

50.88

45.06

49.00

2008

36.52

40.60

46.00

51.40

45.30

48.54

2009

37.41

40.56

47.01

51.10

46.26

50.88

``` ::: ::: You can get more fancy and use a scale from the `scales` package: ::: {.cell hash='index_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-17_fc28493e9afd0ed3d5e77ef42f89a5ba'} ```{.r .cell-code} penguin_flextable_4 |> color(color = scales::col_numeric(palette = "viridis", domain = c(30, 52))) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr} ``` Warning: Some values were outside the color scale and will be treated as NA ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output-display} ```{=html}

year

Adelie

Chinstrap

Gentoo

female

male

female

male

female

male

2007

37.92

39.95

46.57

50.88

45.06

49.00

2008

36.52

40.60

46.00

51.40

45.30

48.54

2009

37.41

40.56

47.01

51.10

46.26

50.88

``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} penguin_flextable_4 |> color(color = scales::col_bin(palette = "viridis", domain = c(30, 60), bins = 3)) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr} ``` Warning: Some values were outside the color scale and will be treated as NA ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output-display} ```{=html}

year

Adelie

Chinstrap

Gentoo

female

male

female

male

female

male

2007

37.92

39.95

46.57

50.88

45.06

49.00

2008

36.52

40.60

46.00

51.40

45.30

48.54

2009

37.41

40.56

47.01

51.10

46.26

50.88

``` ::: ::: You can also select rows or columns with the `i` and `j` arguments, using formula syntax. To target rows, provide `i` with a formula to filter through the rows. Here we color in red rows for years greater than 2007: ::: {.cell hash='index_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-18_d1677b76b89cfa08237db81716401dad'} ```{.r .cell-code} penguin_flextable_4 |> color(i = ~ year > 2007, color = "red" ) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ```{=html}

year

Adelie

Chinstrap

Gentoo

female

male

female

male

female

male

2007

37.92

39.95

46.57

50.88

45.06

49.00

2008

36.52

40.60

46.00

51.40

45.30

48.54

2009

37.41

40.56

47.01

51.10

46.26

50.88

``` ::: ::: You can restrict this to specific columns with the `j` argument: ::: {.cell hash='index_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-19_f1de822af156b78afc5c48bbd27b0bae'} ```{.r .cell-code} penguin_flextable_4 |> color(i = ~ year > 2007, j = c("year", "Adelie_female"), color = "red" ) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ```{=html}

year

Adelie

Chinstrap

Gentoo

female

male

female

male

female

male

2007

37.92

39.95

46.57

50.88

45.06

49.00

2008

36.52

40.60

46.00

51.40

45.30

48.54

2009

37.41

40.56

47.01

51.10

46.26

50.88

``` ::: ::: ### Getting `flextable`s into Word There are three main ways to get a `flextable` into Word: open a temporary preview file that you can copy from with `print(preview = "docx")`, save to a Word file with `save_as_docx()`, or insert into an existing Word document with the `officer` package. #### Temporary Word file This is probably the easiest method. The following code opens a new temporary document in Word (assuming it's installed on your computer) that contains the `flextable` object. ::: {.cell hash='index_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-20_b72233f92727c34570515ce90c53616a'} ```{.r .cell-code} penguin_flextable_4 |> print(preview = "docx") ``` ::: That's it! You can now copy and paste that table wherever you need. NB: this creates a *temporary file* which will be deleted when your R session closes, so save any output you want in a separate document. #### Save to a new Word file `save_as_docx` will do as the name suggests---insert the `flextable` into a new .docx file whose location you specify: ::: {.cell hash='index_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-21_0315c8fcb2723853bd262339c6869ee3'} ```{.r .cell-code} penguin_flextable_4 |> save_as_docx(path = "penguin_table.docx") # I find it necessary to explicitly name the path argument ``` ::: #### Import into an existing Word file. The package `officer` lets you read a Word document into R, manipulate it, and save it again with any additions or changes. Read in an existing Word document with `officer::read_docx()`. Here I'll read the `penguin_table.docx` document we created above.: ::: {.cell hash='index_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-22_1755dd840246a6502c2e60d118527343'} ```{.r .cell-code} penguin_doc <- officer::read_docx("penguin_table.docx") ``` ::: Now add your `flextable` with `flextable::body_add_flextable()`: ::: {.cell hash='index_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-23_b3faecde7a49e3a93f63b78dacee4cab'} ```{.r .cell-code} penguin_doc <- flextable::body_add_flextable(penguin_doc, penguin_flextable_4) ``` ::: And finally, save this Word object as a Word document: ::: {.cell hash='index_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-24_cfa46f028034ebad593f7092463786ff'} ```{.r .cell-code} penguin_doc |> print(target = "penguin_table.docx") ``` ::: ## Conclusion That's it! `flextable` has a bunch more functionality, but these are the things I find myself using regularly. Check out [the `flextable` page](https://davidgohel.github.io/flextable/) or [the `flextable` book](https://ardata-fr.github.io/flextable-book/) (free online).
Session info and package versions ::: {.cell hash='index_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-26_dfcf0a79facc89701596347f92e73150'} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Session info ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` setting value version R version 4.4.0 (2024-04-24) os macOS Sonoma 14.4.1 system aarch64, darwin20 ui X11 language (EN) collate en_US.UTF-8 ctype en_US.UTF-8 tz America/Chicago date 2024-05-17 pandoc 3.2 @ /opt/homebrew/bin/ (via rmarkdown) ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Packages ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` package
